column1: Sorong is the largest city of the Indonesian province of West Papua. The city is located on the western tip of the island of New Guinea with its only land borders being with Sorong Regency. It is the gateway to Indonesia's Raja Ampat Islands
column2: species rich coral reef islands in an area considered the heart of the world's coral reef biodiversity.  It also is the logistics hub for Indonesia's thriving eastern oil and gas frontier. Sorong has experienced exponential growth since 2010
column3: and further growth is anticipated as Sorong becomes linked by road to other frontier towns in Papua's Bird's Head Peninsula. The city had a population of 190
column4: 625 at the 2010 Census; the latest official estimate (as at mid 2019) is 254
column5: 294.  It is served by Domine Eduard Osok Airport.

column1: The origin of Sorong's name comes from the word Soren
column2: which means "deep and wavy ocean" in the Biak language. The name was first used by the Biak-Numfor people who sailed to different islands before they finally decided to settle down in Raja Ampat Islands. When the Biak-Numfor people came to the place called "Daratan Maladum"
column3: they decided to call it Soren. After centuries of contact with Chinese merchants
column5: and people from Maluku and Sangihe-Talaud
column6: the name underwent further change into Sorong.

column1: Sorong experiences the tropical rainforest climate (Af)
column2: as there is no real dry season throughout the year. The wettest month is June
column3: with a total precipitation of 373 millimetres (14.7 in)
column4: while the driest month is February
column5: with a total precipitation of 180 millimetres (7.1 in). The excessive precipitation is caused by the monsoon. The temperature variation remains constant throughout the year. The temperature difference between the hottest month and the coolest month is 1.2 °C (2.2 °F). The hottest month is November

column1: A container port is to be built in Sorong with an annual container-handling capacity of 500
column2: 000 twenty-foot equivalent units (TEUs) and cost Rp.800 billion (US$93.6 million). Construction began in early 2012 and was expected to be complete in mid-2013
